node.contents: What are your requirements for your charting library? What is the main place the charts will be viewed? In app? On the web? As an exported graphic?

astNode.text: What are your requirements for your charting library? What is the main place the charts will be viewed? In app? On the web? As an exported graphic?

node.contents: Nothing exotic. It´s an app that draws data from a DB, does "SELECT COUNT"s on several entity properties, compares them to hardcoded numerical limits and displays the results as a function over time.The charts should be zoomable, because the needed time-stretch (x-axis) will vary from 4 years to a couple of months and it would be very nice if i could overlay 3 or 4 graphs with different y-axis definitions (different functions over the same time-stretch). I´m not a native english seaker, i hope i make myself sufficiently understood :)

astNode.text: Nothing exotic. node.contents: On the main window of the application, a plain java desktop application. Export to PDF should definitely be an option.

astNode.text: On the main window of the application, a plain java desktop application. Export to PDF should definitely be an option.

node.contents: Where do the charts display, though? On a website? Exported as PDFs, ect?

node.contents: first of all: I did read all the other similar questions and i have taken a look at JFreeChart, which seems to be the weapon of choice for producing charts for a Java desktop app. It would actually suit my needs too, but the project seems to be dead.The forums are down, last update was in 2009.

astNode.text: first of all: I did read all the other similar questions and i have taken a look at JFreeChart, which seems to be the weapon of choice for producing charts for a Java desktop app. It would actually suit my needs too, but the project seems to be dead.The forums are down, last update was in 2009.

node.contents: Question is, is there any other library comparable to JFreeChart, or should i use JFreeChart anyway, because it´s awesome and i will never need support from the -now dead- official forums ?

astNode.text: Question is, is there any other library comparable to JFreeChart, or should i use JFreeChart anyway, because it´s awesome and i will never need support from the -now dead- official forums ?

node.contents: Your thoughts on this would be highly appreciated.

astNode.text: Your thoughts on this would be highly appreciated.

node.contents: +1 for JFreechart.

astNode.text: +1 for JFreechart.

node.contents: I suggest you take another look at JFreeChart. It is very comprehensive and if you have problems I'm sure you'll find quick answers to them here on SO.

astNode.text: I suggest you take another look at JFreeChart. It is very comprehensive and if you have problems I'm sure you'll find quick answers to them here on SO.

node.contents: This JFreeChart FAQ lists alternatives but they are not as powerful.

astNode.text: This JFreeChart FAQ lists alternatives but they are not as powerful.

node.contents: One downside is that charts4j and google charts api require you to be online because they use google servers to draw the charts.

astNode.text: One downside is that charts4j and google charts api require you to be online because they use google servers to draw the charts.

node.contents: Yeah :( that's a major downside.

astNode.text: Yeah :( that's a major downside.

node.contents: Have you seen Google Chart API?

astNode.text: Have you seen Google Chart API?

node.contents: And some third party Java client libraries for the same.

astNode.text: And some third party Java client libraries for the same.

node.contents: I used for test purpose some job with charts4j It's pretty active as a project, and quite complete, but it depends on what you'll need to display.

astNode.text: I used for test purpose some job with charts4j It's pretty active as a project, and quite complete, but it depends on what you'll need to display.

node.contents: Oh and I used also ILOG (Now IBM) JViews Charts&Diagrammer to display a plane dashboard. With good coding you can achieve nice performance. But if I remember it's far from free ;)

astNode.text: Oh and I used also ILOG (Now IBM) JViews Charts&Diagrammer to display a plane dashboard. With good coding you can achieve nice performance. But if I remember it's far from free ;)

node.contents: Have you seen iReport? Very reliable and versatile. It provides a WYSIWYG environment to design reports and Graphs. It is a simple and high level interface that sits on top of JasperReports and JFreeChart that takes care of the "dirty work".

astNode.text: Have you seen iReport? Very reliable and versatile. It provides a WYSIWYG environment to design reports and Graphs. It is a simple and high level interface that sits on top of JasperReports and JFreeChart that takes care of the "dirty work".

node.contents: Just looked over the examples and decided to give XChart a try in my next project. On first look, it doesn´t look as customizable as JFreechart, BUT: the code examples are very brief and self-explanatory. Thanks for sharing, herrtim.

astNode.text: Just looked over the examples and decided to give XChart a try in my next project. On first look, it doesn´t look as customizable as JFreechart, BUT: the code examples are very brief and self-explanatory. Thanks for sharing, herrtim.

node.contents: With the StyleMananger you can customize almost anything visually on the chart. See [LineChart03](https://github.com/timmolter/XChart/blob/develop/xchart-demo/src/main/java/com/xeiam/xchart/demo/charts/line/LineChart03.java) .You could also set a Theme and even create your own. See [ThemeChart02](https://github.com/timmolter/XChart/blob/develop/xchart-demo/src/main/java/com/xeiam/xchart/demo/charts/line/LineChart03.java).

astNode.text: With the StyleMananger you can customize almost anything visually on the chart. See [LineChart03](https://github.com/timmolter/XChart/blob/develop/xchart-demo/src/main/java/com/xeiam/xchart/demo/charts/line/LineChart03.java) .You could also set a Theme and even create your own. See [ThemeChart02](https://github.com/timmolter/XChart/blob/develop/xchart-demo/src/main/java/com/xeiam/xchart/demo/charts/line/LineChart03.java).

node.contents: Take a look at XChart. It's actively developed, and with the recent 2.0.0 release, it has many features of a mature charting library. The jar is on ~86 KB and it has no dependencies. It's licensed under Apache 2.0 and is hosted on Github. Disclaimer: I'm the lead developer of the project.
